physDesc.p: Some erasures in this homily alter 'naenig'-forms to 'naen'-forms. There are also a few additions by what may be a further hand; this hand adds 'aenig ðinc dydon;' on 109r, and possibly makes some alterations on 111v-112r. Possibly the same hand adds 'grere' and '7 þeah' on 38r and some other things on 38r, plus possibly one 'nes' inserted on 38v.

handNote.p: Main scribe of the manuscript. A square Anglo-Saxon miniscule, described by Ker as 'handsome'.

This is hand of the main Rochester reviser. Ker describes the hand as 'sprawling, but firm and well-marked', with e slightly ascending and open at the top. It should be noted that Ker's palaeographical description on p. 367 erroneously states that this hand is responsible for a homily on Paulinus in 'art. 76', but in fact that added Paulinus homily is Ker's art. 75. Digipal terms this hand the 'Principal Corrector'. In this homily, it appears based on the unique tool in use that this hand repeatedly changes the lemma for 'broðor' e.g., to 'broðra' in homiletic address phrases.
A compact, somewhat squareish emending hand, baseline tending to slant downwards to the right. Frequent long s, dotted y; uses triple punctus insertions. e often open at the top.
Emending hand, probably saec. xii (?), one straight-backed d, caroline s, notable roofing to a.
Emending hand that uses double-point insertion marks, cf. 114r, 118r.
